PM.recommendation: Codeine is ineffective in Poor Metabolizers. Use alternative opioids such as morphine or oxycodone at standard doses.
PM.mechanism: CYP2D6 converts codeine to morphine. PMs cannot activate the prodrug, leading to no analgesic effect.

IM.recommendation: Reduce codeine dose by 25-50% or use an alternative. Monitor closely for inadequate analgesia.
IM.mechanism: Reduced CYP2D6 activity leads to partial conversion of codeine to morphine.

NM.mechanism: Normal metabolizer — expected drug conversion and analgesic response.

UM.recommendation: CONTRAINDICATED. Ultrarapid metabolizers convert codeine to morphine too quickly causing potentially fatal opioid toxicity. Use alternative opioids.
UM.mechanism: Excess CYP2D6 activity results in dangerously high morphine plasma levels.

PM.recommendation: Tramadol is ineffective in Poor Metabolizers. Consider alternative analgesic.
PM.mechanism: CYP2D6 converts tramadol to active O-desmethyltramadol. PMs cannot activate the prodrug.

IM.recommendation: Consider reducing tramadol dose. Monitor for adequate pain control.

UM.recommendation: CONTRAINDICATED. Risk of life-threatening opioid toxicity. Use alternative analgesic.
UM.mechanism: Ultrarapid conversion produces excessive O-desmethyltramadol concentrations.

PM.recommendation: Clopidogrel is ineffective in CYP2C19 Poor Metabolizers. Use prasugrel or ticagrelor if not contraindicated.
PM.mechanism: CYP2C19 is required to convert clopidogrel (prodrug) to its active thiol metabolite. PMs lack this conversion.

IM.recommendation: Consider alternative antiplatelet therapy. If clopidogrel is used, monitor platelet function.
IM.mechanism: Reduced CYP2C19 activity leads to subtherapeutic active metabolite levels.

NM.mechanism: Normal CYP2C19 activity — adequate prodrug activation expected.

RM.recommendation: Standard dosing. Rapid metabolizers may have slightly higher active metabolite levels but generally tolerate standard doses.
RM.mechanism: Enhanced CYP2C19 activity increases clopidogrel activation.

PM.recommendation: Reduce omeprazole dose. PMs have dramatically increased drug exposure (AUC ~5x higher). Standard dose may cause drug accumulation.
PM.mechanism: CYP2C19 is the main metabolizer of omeprazole. PMs have markedly reduced clearance.

IM.recommendation: Consider dose reduction. Monitor for side effects.

RM.recommendation: Rapid metabolizers may require higher doses for adequate acid suppression. Consider doubling the standard dose.
RM.mechanism: Increased CYP2C19 activity leads to rapid omeprazole clearance, reducing efficacy.

PM.recommendation: Significantly reduce warfarin dose (up to 50-75% reduction). Start with lowest effective dose and titrate cautiously. Intensive INR monitoring required.
PM.mechanism: CYP2C9 is the primary metabolizer of S-warfarin (the active enantiomer). PMs have severely reduced clearance, causing drug accumulation and bleeding risk.

IM.recommendation: Reduce warfarin starting dose by 25-50%. More frequent INR monitoring recommended during initiation.
IM.mechanism: Reduced CYP2C9 activity leads to higher warfarin exposure and increased bleeding risk.

NM.recommendation: Standard warfarin dosing. Use CPIC dosing algorithm incorporating VKORC1/CYP2C19 variants.

PM.recommendation: CONTRAINDICATED at standard doses. If thiopurine is required, reduce dose by 90% (10% of standard) and monitor weekly blood counts. Consider non-thiopurine alternatives.
PM.mechanism: TPMT deficiency causes accumulation of cytotoxic thioguanine nucleotides (TGNs), leading to severe myelosuppression.

IM.recommendation: Reduce azathioprine dose to 30-70% of standard dose. Frequent CBC monitoring required.
IM.mechanism: Intermediate TPMT activity leads to moderately elevated TGN levels and myelosuppression risk.

NM.mechanism: Adequate TPMT-mediated methylation prevents TGN accumulation.

PM.recommendation: Reduce dose by 90% and monitor blood counts weekly. Consider alternative therapy.
PM.mechanism: TPMT deficiency leads to accumulation of 6-thioguanine nucleotides causing myelosuppression.

IM.recommendation: Reduce to 30-50% of standard dose with close CBC monitoring.
IM.mechanism: Partial TPMT deficiency increases TGN exposure.

PM.recommendation: CONTRAINDICATED. DPD deficiency causes life-threatening 5-FU toxicity (severe mucositis, neutropenia, neurotoxicity). Use alternative non-fluoropyrimidine therapy.
PM.mechanism: DPYD (DPD) catabolizes >80% of 5-FU. Deficiency leads to massive drug accumulation and organ-threatening toxicity.

IM.recommendation: Reduce starting dose by 50%. Up-titrate only if tolerated. Monitor closely for toxicity.
IM.mechanism: Reduced DPD activity leads to higher 5-FU exposure and toxicity risk.

PM.recommendation: CONTRAINDICATED. DPD-deficient patients cannot metabolize the 5-FU generated from capecitabine. Life-threatening toxicity expected.
PM.mechanism: Capecitabine is converted to 5-FU in vivo. DPD deficiency causes 5-FU accumulation.

IM.recommendation: Reduce starting dose by 25-50%. Intensify toxicity monitoring.

PM.recommendation: Reduce irinotecan starting dose by at least 50%. Some guidelines recommend dose reduction even for IM. Use lowest effective dose with toxicity monitoring.
PM.mechanism: UGT1A1 glucuronidates SN-38 (active metabolite of irinotecan) for elimination. Reduced UGT1A1 activity causes SN-38 accumulation and severe diarrhea/neutropenia.

IM.recommendation: Consider starting at lower dose (75-80% of standard). Monitor for GI toxicity and neutropenia.
IM.mechanism: Partial reduction in SN-38 glucuronidation increases drug exposure.

NM.mechanism: Normal UGT1A1 activity — adequate SN-38 glucuronidation expected.

RM.recommendation: May require higher doses for adequate efficacy. Monitor therapeutic response.
RM.mechanism: Enhanced UGT1A1 activity may reduce SN-38 exposure and drug efficacy.

PM.recommendation: Standard tacrolimus dosing with typical TDM monitoring. Non-expressers require lower doses.
PM.mechanism: CYP3A5 non-expressers (*3/*3) have reduced tacrolimus clearance.

NM.recommendation: Increase tacrolimus starting dose (1.5-2x standard). Perform standard TDM.
NM.mechanism: CYP3A5 expressers have higher tacrolimus clearance.

PM.recommendation: Reduce amitriptyline dose by 50% or avoid. Consider alternative antidepressant not metabolized by CYP2D6.
PM.mechanism: CYP2D6 metabolizes amitriptyline. PMs have markedly elevated drug levels, increasing anticholinergic and cardiac toxicity risk.

IM.recommendation: Consider 25-50% dose reduction. Monitor for side effects.
IM.mechanism: Reduced CYP2D6 activity leads to higher amitriptyline exposure.

UM.recommendation: Ultrarapid metabolizers may require higher doses for efficacy. Consider alternative antidepressant.
UM.mechanism: Increased CYP2D6 activity dramatically reduces amitriptyline plasma levels.
